review.title: Learning to Blend Computer Game Levels
review.abstract: We present an approach to generate novel computer game levels that blend different game concepts in an unsupervised fashion. Our primary contribution is an analogical reasoning process to construct blends between level design models learned from gameplay videos. The models represent probabilistic relationships between elements in the game. An analogical reasoning process maps features between two models to produce blended models that can then generate new level chunks. As a proof-of-concept we train our system on the classic platformer game Super Mario Bros. due to its highly-regarded and well understood level design. We evaluate the extent to which the models represent stylistic level design knowledge and demonstrate the ability of our system to explain levels that were blended by human expert designers.

sections.heading: System Overview
sections.text: The goal of our work is to develop a computer system that is capable of creating novel levels of play by mixing different concepts from the game. For example, we want to create a layer of Super Mario Bros. in which Mario floats through an underwater castle. Our system as a whole can be understood as a three-part system that works one after the other. First, our system automatically derives levels from gameplay videos and categorizes these sections according to their characteristics. Second, the system derives probabilistic graphic models from each category. At this point in the process, it can be used to generate levels of play that are closely related but from existing levels of play (Guzdial and Riedl 2016).

sections.heading: Model Learning
sections.text: Our system learns a generative, probabilistic model of the form for shaping relationships from gameplay videos. Given the focus of this work on mixing, we give here a brief description of the learning process of the model, for more details see (Guzdial and Riedl 2016). These types of probabilistic graphical models, common in the field of object and scene modeling, require a number of similar examples as input. These sets are typically categories of 3D models decided by an inhuman expert. Since the input to our system is gameplay video, we need to (1) determine what input a probabilistic model should learn and (2) how to uncontrollably categorize this input to ensure the required similarity. For the input into our system, we define the level chunk, a short segment of a level. sections.heading: Evaluation
sections.text: In this section, we present the results of two different assessments designed to demonstrate the benefits of our system: the first is a human study that shows that our probabilistic graphical model captures people's intuitions about the level design style; the second is a case study that shows that our system's blended models can explain human-made expert blends far better than if the system is not allowed to merge models.

sections.heading: Example Output
sections.text: To generate complete levels, our system determines the sequence of L-nodes that best explains the sequence of uniform blocks of a target plane. Each L-node in this sequence is then asked to generate a novel level chunk, and the sequence of generated chunks represents a plane. Figure 8 and Figure 9 represent (according to our system) high-quality levels using a blending target of the world 9-1 and 9-3, respectively. In comparison, we present Figure 10, which represents a low-grade aperture plane, and Figure 11, which represents a high-quality level generated by the complete aperture model. The difference between low and high scoring levels should be evident from their structure, with Figure 10 comprising individual, oddly placed blocks and a floating castle. Furthermore, we identify a lack of differences between the aperture and full aperture models, with Figure 9 and 11 appearing to be very similar in quality, but not showing the generated levels from Figure 9 and 9 are perfect.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we presented techniques to learn probabilistic models from gameplay videos and merge these models into new level types. We conducted a study on human subjects to evaluate the ability of our model to capture level design styles as a measure of structural probability. We found strong evidence of this in the form of a strong correlation between the participants "style ranking and the rankings of our system. We demonstrated through two case studies that our system is capable of explaining blended levels from human experts and mixing models that evaluate these levels significantly better than the unblended models. Taken together, these represent a system that is able to learn design, evaluate design like a human and is able to expand this knowledge to explain new domains through concept blending.
